questions.text: All Trans retinoic acid is used in the treatment of tumours associated with:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) is used in Acute Promyelocytic Leukaemia (APML)
  • APML is characterized by the t(15;17) translocation, forming the PML-RARA fusion gene
  • ATRA promotes differentiation of promyelocytes, inducing remission
  • BCR-ABL is found in CML, treated with tyrosine kinase inhibitors (Option A ruled out)
  • cMYC is involved in Burkitt lymphoma, not treated with ATRA (Option C ruled out)
  • CEBPA mutations occur in AML, but are not targets for ATRA therapy (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • ATRA is the treatment for PML-RARA-positive APML
  • Works by maturing malignant promyelocytes
  • t(15;17) translocation is the molecular hallmark of this disease

questions.text: A patient presented with intermittent fever, no weight loss. loss, no anorexia, retroperitoneal mass. Peripheral smear findings were normal. Gross and microscopic images of the mass are given. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Castleman's disease can present as a solitary retroperitoneal mass with systemic symptoms like fever
  • Gross image: Well-circumscribed, tan-orange mass with lobulated surface
  • Microscopic image: Shows hyaline vascular pattern - concentric layering of lymphocytes around germinal centres ("onion-skinning") and hyalinized vessels
  • Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma typically shows nodal involvement, with abnormal smear or bone marrow findings (Option A ruled out)
  • Angiolymphoid hyperplasia is usually cutaneous and does not produce deep-seated retroperitoneal masses (Option C ruled out)
  • All of the above is incorrect since the features match only Castleman disease (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Castleman disease can be unicentric or multicentric, often retroperitoneal or mediastinal
  • Hyaline vascular type shows "onion-skin" pattern around follicles
  • Diagnosis is clinical + histopathologic with no malignant smear findings

questions.text: HHV-8 is related to all, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • HHV-8 (Human Herpesvirus 8) is associated with:
    • Kaposi sarcoma (vascular tumour) (Option B)
    • Primary effusion lymphoma (a rare B-cell lymphoma) (Option A)
    • Multicentric Castleman disease (particularly the plasmablastic variant) (Option C)
  • Adult T-cell lymphoma is caused by HTLV-1, not HHV-8

Key Takeaways:

  • HHV-8 is linked to Kaposi sarcoma, Primary effusion lymphoma, and Castleman disease
  • Adult T-cell lymphoma is caused by HTLV-1, not HHV-8
  • Viral associations are key in differentiating hematologic neoplasms

questions.text: Which of the following represents the marked area in the histology of a lymph node?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The mantle zone is the darkly stained ring that surrounds the pale germinal centre
  • It contains naïve B cells arranged concentrically
  • The arrow in the image is pointing to this peripheral, densely packed layer
  • The marginal zone lies outside the mantle, typically in splenic follicles (Option B ruled out)
  • The paracortical area is located outside the follicle, rich in T cells (Option C ruled out)
  • The germinal centre appears pale due to active proliferation of B cells (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • The mantle zone encircles the germinal centre and stains darker
  • Composed of small, resting B lymphocytes
  • Distinct from the paracortex (T-cell zone) and the marginal zone

questions.text: Which of the following cells will increase in case of parasite infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Eosinophils (Cell D) are bilobed granulocytes with reddish-orange cytoplasmic granules
  • Play a key role in defence against parasitic infections, especially helminths
  • Their granules contain major basic protein and eosinophil peroxidase, toxic to parasites

Explanation of other options:

A (Option A): Lymphocyte - small cell with round, dark nucleus and thin rim of cytoplasm; associated with viral responses

B (Option B): Monocyte - largest WBC, with kidney-shaped nucleus and abundant cytoplasm; involved in phagocytosis

C (Option C): Neutrophil - multilobed nucleus, pale cytoplasmic granules; key responder in bacterial infections

Key Takeaways:

  • Eosinophils rise in parasitic infections, especially helminths
  • Identified by bilobed nuclei and bright eosinophilic granules
  • Other WBCs respond to viruses (lymphocytes) or bacteria (neutrophils)

questions.text: Identify the arrow-marked cell in the given condition below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The arrow-marked cell shows a round eccentric nucleus, abundant basophilic cytoplasm, and a clear perinuclear hof (Golgi zone)
  • This is classic morphology for a plasma cell, which is a terminally differentiated B-cell responsible for antibody secretion

Explanation of other options:

Macrophage (Option A): Large cells with abundant vacuolated cytoplasm, often containing phagocytosed debris

Lymphocyte (Option B): Small round cell with dense nucleus and scant cytoplasm, lacking perinuclear hof

Eosinophil (Option D): Bilobed nucleus with bright eosinophilic (red-orange) cytoplasmic granules

Key Takeaways:

  • Plasma cells are identified by an eccentric nucleus, clock-face chromatin, and perinuclear hof
  • Frequently seen in chronic inflammation and plasma cell neoplasms
  • Differentiation from lymphocytes and macrophages is essential on a smear

choices.text: Done for the diagnosis of infiltrative and granulomatous diseases
No need for breath-holding during the procedure.
It can be done in the prone or lateral position.
A platelet count of <40000/mL is a contraindication

questions.text: About the given instrument below, all of the following statements are true, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The instrument shown is a Jamshidi bone marrow biopsy needle
  • Bone marrow biopsy can be done even with platelet counts <40,000/mL using platelet transfusions if necessary
  • It is not an absolute contraindication

Explanation of other options:

Done for diagnosis of infiltrative and granulomatous diseases (Option A): True-marrow biopsy helps diagnose infiltrative conditions like tuberculosis, leukaemia, lymphoma

No need for breath holding during the procedure (Option B): True-typically done at the iliac crest under local anaesthesia; respiration does not affect safety

Can be done in prone or lateral position (Option C): True-both positions are acceptable depending on patient comfort and operator preference

Key Takeaways:

  • Jamshidi needle is used for bone marrow biopsy, often 14-18 gauge
  • Thrombocytopenia is not an absolute contraindication
  • Useful for hematologic and infiltrative disease workup

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presents complaining of severe fatigue, which began 4 months ago and has gradually worsened. On examination, she has moderate hepatosplenomegaly with normal examination of the heart, lungs, and skin. A complete blood count shows a leukocyte count of 150 × 10^9 cells/L, haemoglobin level of 9.8 g/dL, and platelet count of 424 × 10^9 cells/L/L. A peripheral blood smear shows immature leukocyte forms as well as teardrop-shaped erythrocytes and nucleated red cells. Cytogenetic testing is negative for the BCR-ABL1 translocation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fatigue, hepatosplenomegaly and gradual symptom onset suggest a chronic process
  • Leukocytosis (150 × 109/L) with anemia (Hb 9.8 g/dL) and thrombocytosis (platelets 424 × 109/L) favors a chronic myeloproliferative disorder
  • Teardrop-shaped erythrocytes (dacrocytes) and nucleated RBCs are classic for bone marrow fibrosis(Myelofibrosis)
  • Immature myeloid cells in the blood reflect extramedullary hematopoiesis

Explanation of other options:

Chronic myelogenous leukaemia (Option A): Negative BCR-ABL1 rules out Chronic Myelogenous Leukaemia

Acute myelogenous leukaemia (Option B): Presents acutely with blasts, not chronic symptoms and dacrocytes

β-thalassemia major (Option C): Presents in early childhood with severe anaemia and bone deformities, not late-onset pancytosis and dacrocytes

Key Takeaways:

  • Teardrop cells and nucleated RBCs suggest myelophthisic processes, like myelofibrosis
  • Negative BCR-ABL1 helps exclude CML
  • Gradual symptom onset with hepatosplenomegaly points to chronic myeloproliferative neoplasms

choices.text: Positive JAK2 mutation on reverse transcription PCR
9,22 translocation on fluorescence in situ hybridisation
Tartarate-resistant acid phosphatase activity on peripheral blood film
Teardrop-shaped erythrocytes on a peripheral blood smear

questions.text: A 76-year-old Caucasian man presents to his physician because of severe itching following warm baths and showers. These episodes are not associated with a visible rash, and the patient reports trying multiple different soaps and shampoos with no change in the symptoms. On examination, he appears to be his stated age, ruddy cyanosis of the face is noted, and heart and lungs are normal to auscultation. His spleen is slightly enlarged. His serum leukocyte count is 14.3 × 10^9 cells/L, haemoglobin is 20.1 g/dL, and platelet count is 850 × 10^9 cells/L/L. Which of the following is likely to be demonstrated on additional testing?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pruritus after warm baths (aquagenic pruritus) is a classic symptom of polycythemia vera
  • Ruddy cyanosis and splenomegaly are typical findings in polycythemia vera
  • Elevated hemoglobin (20.1 g/dL), leukocytosis (14.3 × 109/L), and thrombocytosis (850 × 109/L) indicate a myeloproliferative disorder
  • JAK2 V617F mutation is found in ~95% of polycythemia vera

Explanation of other options:

9,22 translocation on fluorescence in situ hybridisation (Option B): Seen in chronic myelogenous leukaemia (CML), not polycythemia vera

Tartate-resistant acid phosphatase activity on peripheral blood film (Option C): Characteristic of hairy cell leukaemia

Teardrop-shaped erythrocytes on peripheral blood smear (Option D): Typical of myelofibrosis, not polycythemia vera

Key Takeaways:

  • Aquagenic pruritus is a hallmark of polycythemia vera
  • JAK2 mutation confirms diagnosis in most cases
  • Elevated RBCs, WBCs, and platelets point toward polycythemia vera

questions.text: How will you differentiate mediastinal mass from a thymoma differentiating it from ALL?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Thymoma contains epithelial cells, which express cytokeratin: a marker for epithelial origin
  • T-cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukaemia (T-ALL) originates from lymphoid precursors and expresses lymphoid markers
  • CD1a, CD3, and TdT are lymphoid markers seen in T-ALL, not specific for thymoma (Options B, C, D ruled out)
  • Cytokeratin is not expressed in lymphoid neoplasms like T-ALL (only in thymoma epithelium)

Key Takeaways:

  • Cytokeratin positivity helps identify epithelial tumours like thymoma
  • T-ALL is positive for TdT, CD1a, and CD3, not cytokeratin
  • Mediastinal mass differential includes thymoma vs T-ALL - immunophenotyping is essential

questions.text: A patient presented with painless b/l proptosis. What is the next investigation to diagnose it as chloroma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Chloroma (myeloid sarcoma) presents as an extramedullary mass of immature myeloid cells, often involving the orbit, causing bilateral painless proptosis
  • Peripheral smear may show blasts with Auer rods, aiding early diagnosis
  • Myeloid lineage is confirmed by cytochemical staining (e.g., MPO positivity)
  • Blood haemoglobin and platelet count are nonspecific and do not confirm myeloid origin (Options A and C ruled out)
  • Bone marrow reticulin assesses fibrosis, not helpful for diagnosing chloroma (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Peripheral smear is essential for detecting blasts and Auer rods in chloroma
  • Chloroma often involvesthe orbit/paranasal sinuses and suggests underlying AML
  • Early smear evaluation guides further immunophenotyping and cytogenetics

questions.text: All of the following are seen in the development of T lymphocytes at a point; except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • TdT is expressed in immature lymphoid cells, including developing T cells (Option A)
  • CD34 is a stem cell marker seen in early hematopoietic progenitors, including T-cell precursors (Option B)
  • CD1a is a marker of cortical thymocytes, indicating immature T-cell development (Option D)
  • PAX5 is a B-cell specific transcription factor, not involved in T-cell development

Key Takeaways:

  • Understanding lineage markers is critical for hematolymphoid neoplasm classification

questions.text: Which of the following blasts are positive for Non-Specific Esterase stain?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Non-specific esterase stain is characteristically positive in monoblasts, which helps identify monocytic subtypes of AML (e.g., M4, M5)
  • Myeloblasts are typically positive for myeloperoxidase (MPO) and Sudan Black B, not non-specific esterase (Option A ruled out)
  • Lymphoblasts show PAS positivity, but are negative for non-specific esterase (Option C ruled out)
  • Megakaryoblasts are usually identified with Platelet Peroxidase or Factor VIII staining, not non-specific esterase (Option D ruled out)

Cytochemical profile in leukemia (from Robbins):

Key Takeaways:

  • Monoblasts are positive for non-specific esterase, helping subtype monocytic leukaemias
  • Myeloblasts and lymphoblasts differ in their cytochemical stain profiles
  • Cytochemical stains remain crucial in differentiating leukaemia subtypes

questions.text: Which of the following conditions frequently gives a dry tap on bone marrow aspiration?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hairy cell leukaemia (HCL) is a chronic B-cell leukaemia with fine cytoplasmic projections
  • Cells express CD20, CD11c, and CD103 - the latter two being diagnostically significant
  • Bone marrow infiltration leads to fibrosis, causing frequent dry taps on aspiration
  • Diagnosis often requires a bone marrow biopsy due to unsuccessful aspiration

Explanation of other options:

Megaloblastic anaemia (Option A): Shows hypercellular marrow, not fibrosis

Iron deficiency anaemia (Option B): Has normal or hypercellular marrow with increased erythroid precursors

None of the above (Option D): Dry tap is not expected in either of the above conditions

Key Takeaways:

  • Hairy cell leukemia is classically associated with dry tap due to marrow fibrosis
  • CD11c and CD103 help distinguish HCL from other B-cell neoplasms
  • A bone marrow biopsy is essential when aspiration fails

questions.text: Which is the most common type of Acute myeloid leukaemia in association with Down's syndrome in a child of 1 year of age?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Acute megakaryocytic leukemia (AMKL) is the most common type of AML in children with Down syndrome, especially below 4 years of age
  • This subtype is linked to GATA1 mutations in Down syndrome-associated leukemia
  • B-ALL becomes more common after age 4 in these children
  • Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) is associated with t(15;17) and DIC risk but not with Down syndrome (Option A ruled out)
  • Acute monocytic leukemia shows non-specific esterase positivity and lacks Down syndrome association (Option B ruled out)
  • AML with maturation is a broader WHO subtype without specific association to Down syndrome (Option D ruled out)

AML classification table:

Key Takeaways:

  • Acute megakaryocytic leukaemia is the most frequent AML in Down syndrome < 4 years
  • B-ALL becomes more common in Down syndrome after 4 years
  • Recognition of age-specific associations is crucial in pediatric hematologic malignancies

questions.text: Which type of leukaemia shows block positivity on PAS (periodic acid schiff) stain?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Lymphoblasts in Acute Lymphoblastic Leukaemia (ALL) show block positivity with PAS stain due to cytoplasmic glycogen granules
  • PAS stain is useful in identifying lymphoid blasts, which are myeloperoxidase-negative
  • AML shows myeloperoxidase and Sudan Black B positivity, not PAS block positivity (Option B ruled out)
  • CLL is composed of mature lymphocytes and does not show PAS block positivity (Option A ruled out)
  • CML involves mature myeloid cells and does not exhibit PAS block positivity (Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Block PAS positivity is a hallmark of lymphoblasts in ALL
  • Helps distinguish ALL from AML, especially in histochemical staining
  • PAS stain detects glycogen-rich cytoplasm in lymphoblasts

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with cervical lymphadenopathy. Histology of the lymph node shows RS cells with vague nodular formation and background T reactive lymphocytes. The cells were positive for CD20, LCA, EMA and negative for CD15 and CD30. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Nodular lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin lymphoma (NLPHL) is characterized by:
    • Vague nodular architecture
    • Presence of popcorn (LP) cells - variant of Reed-Sternberg cells
    • Background of reactive T cells
    • Immunophenotype: CD20+, LCA+, EMA+, CD15-, CD30-
  • T cell rich B cell lymphoma is a diffuse large B-cell lymphoma with abundant T cells but lacks nodularity and LP cells (Option B ruled out)
  • Nodular sclerosis Hodgkin lymphoma typically shows lacunar cells and is CD15+ and CD30+, not CD20+ (Option C ruled out)
  • CLL usually involves small, mature lymphocytes and lacks RS cells or nodular pattern (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • NLPHL is CD20+, CD15-, CD30-, with nodular pattern and LP cells
  • Immunophenotyping distinguishes NLPHL from classical Hodgkin lymphoma
  • RS-like cells in NLPHL are LCA+ and EMA+, unlike classical HL

questions.text: EBV is not associated with:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • EBV is known to play a role in several lymphoproliferative and malignant disorders, but NLPHL is not associated with EBV.
  • Plasmablastic lymphoma: Strong EBV association, especially in HIV-positive patients.
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma: Classic EBV-related epithelial malignancy.
  • Mixed cellularity Hodgkin disease: Frequently associated with EBV positivity.

Explanation of other options:

Plasmablastic lymphoma (Option B): Strongly EBV-associated, especially in immunocompromised states.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (Option C): EBV DNA and antigens are consistently detected; serves as a diagnostic marker.

Mixed cellularity Hodgkin disease (Option D): One of the classical HL subtypes with strong EBV association.

questions.text: Smudge cells are seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Smudge cells are disrupted fragile lymphocytes seen during smear preparation
  • Seen in CLL, where circulating small, mature-looking lymphocytes are highly fragile
  • Proliferation centres in lymph nodes are pathognomonic for CLL/SLL
  • Absolute lymphocytosis with mature lymphocytes is typical in CLL

Explanation of other options:

Acute lymphocytic leukemia (Option A): Shows lymphoblasts, not fragile mature lymphocytes, and smudge cells are not typical

Acute myeloid leukaemia (Option C): Characterised by myeloblasts and Auer rods; no smudge cells

Chronic myeloid leukaemia (Option D): Shows increased mature granulocytes and basophils; smudge cells not seen

Key Takeaways:

  • Smudge cells are classic for Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia (CLL)
  • CLL features mature, fragile lymphocytes leading to disrupted cells in smears
  • Proliferation centres are diagnostic for CLL/SLL

questions.text: Which of the following immunohistochemistry marker is used in Cyclin D1 negative Mantle cell lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • SOX11 is a sensitive marker for mantle cell lymphoma, particularly useful in cases where Cyclin D1 is negative
  • Mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) typically expresses Cyclin D1, but rare cases may lack its expression
  • In such Cyclin D1-negative MCL, SOX11 positivity helps confirm the diagnosis
  • ITRA1, MYD88, and Annexin V are not diagnostic markers for MCL (Options B, C, D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • SOX11 is a key marker in diagnosing Cyclin D1-negative mantle cell lymphoma
  • Cyclin D1 and SOX11 together help differentiate MCL from other B-cell lymphomas
  • Proper immunohistochemistry is critical for subclassifying non-Hodgkin lymphomas

questions.text: A 35-year-old presented with fever. On examination, he had enlarged and ulcerated tonsils. His peripheral blood smear showed lymphocytosis. Monospot test was negative. Tonsillectomy was done. The biopsy of the same showed large cells mixed with lymphocytes. The cells were positive for CD20, EBVLMP1, MUM1, CD79a. Background cells were positive for CD3. The cells are negative for CD15. Your most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Patient is immunocompetent, with tonsillar ulceration, lymphocytosis, and a negative Monospot test, ruling out infectious mononucleosis
  • Biopsy findings show:
    • Large atypical B cells positive for CD20, CD79a, EBV LMP1, MUM1
    • Background T lymphocytes positive for CD3
    • CD15 negative, helping to exclude Hodgkin lymphoma
  • These findings match EBV-positive diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL)

Table: Key comparison of EBV-related lymphoproliferative disorders

Explanation of other options:

Infectious mononucleosis (Option A): Ruled out by negative Monospot and presence of large B-cell population on biopsy

Hodgkin lymphoma (Option B): Typically CD15 positive, and lacks EBV LMP1 positivity in most subtypes

EBV positive mucocutaneous ulcer (Option D): Occurs in immunocompromised patients; this patient is immunocompetent

Key Takeaways:

  • EBV-positive DLBCL occurs in immunocompetent individuals, often with tonsillar or nodal involvement
  • CD20, MUM1, EBV-LMP1 positivity with CD15 negativity helps distinguish it from Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Always correlate immunophenotyping with clinical context (e.g., immune status, age)

questions.text: Splenic infarction is associated with:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Splenic infarction occurs when there is impaired blood flow due to vascular occlusion, infiltration, or hypercellularity
  • In CML, the spleen becomes massively enlarged from leukemic infiltration, predisposing to vascular congestion and infarction
  • CML is one of the key hematologic disorders associated with splenic infarcts

Causes of Splenic Infarction:

Explanation of other options:

Typhoid (Option A): Though it can cause splenomegaly, infarction is not typical

Thymoma (Option C): A mediastinal tumour; no direct splenic involvement

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (Option D): Predisposes to venous thromboses, especially hepatic or cerebral, not commonly splenic

Key Takeaways:

  • CML is a classic hematologic cause of splenic infarction
  • Infarction may result from massive infiltration, vascular obstruction, or thrombosis
  • Always evaluate for hematologic malignancies in patients with splenomegaly and infarction

questions.text: A boy aged 20 years came to the hospital with the chief complaint of dyspnoea and had a mediastinal mass. Laboratory investigations show leucocytosis and thrombocytopenia. Bone marrow aspiration shows blast count > 20%. Which of the following probable hematolymphoid malignancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A mediastinal mass in a young male with leukocytosis, thrombocytopenia, and blast count >20% is classic for T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (T-ALL)
  • T-ALL often presents with a mediastinal (thymic) mass due to its origin from TdT+ precursor T cells
  • Bone marrow blast count >20% confirmsthe diagnosis of acute leukaemia
  • This presentation is distinct from B-cell neoplasms, which usually do not involve the mediastinum in this age group

Explanation of other options:

Diffuse large B cell lymphoma (Option A): Typically seen in older adults and presents with nodal/extranodal mass, not blasts in marrow

Mediastinal B cell lymphoma (Option C): May occur in young adults but does not present with >20% blasts in marrow

B cell rich T-cell lymphoma (Option D): A rare entity, not typically associated with mediastinal masses or high blast counts

Table: Characteristics of Common Lymphoid Leukaemias and Lymphomas

Key Takeaways:

  • T-ALL presents in adolescent males with a mediastinal mass and marrow blasts >20%
  • TdT positivity and T-cell markers (CD3) help confirm the diagnosis
  • B-cell lymphomas rarely present with a mediastinal mass plus blastemia

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room by his family. Over the past two weeks, he has developed marked fatigue, and his parents have noted pinpoint haemorrhages in his eyelids. On examination, the patient appears ill. His vital signs are temperature of 99.6°F, blood pressure of 100/65 mm Hg, and pulse rate of 102 bpm. The white blood cell count is 87,000 cells/μL, with 92% blasts, haemoglobin of 8.6 g/dL, and platelet count of 68,000 cells/ μL. Of the following, which would genetic testing most likely reveal?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with fatigue, thrombocytopenia (petechiae), anaemia, and leukocytosis with high blast count (92%), which is characteristic of acute leukaemia
  • In a 12-year-old child, the most likely diagnosis is acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL)
  • t(12;21) results in fusion of the TEL (ETV6) and AML1 (RUNX1) genes-the most common translocation in pediatric ALL
  • It is associated with favourable prognosis

Explanation of other options:

t(15;17) (Option A): Found in acute promyelocytic leukaemia (APL), a subtype of AML

t(9;22) (Option B): Philadelphia chromosome, more common in adult ALL and CML

t(11;14) (Option D): Associated with mantle cell lymphoma, not ALL

Key Takeaways:

  • t(12;21) is the most common translocation in childhood ALL
  • High blast count with cytopenias in a child suggests ALL
  • Genetic testing helps in risk stratification and prognosis in leukaemia

questions.text: Leucoerythroblastosis is seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Leukoerythroblastosis refers to the presence of immature myeloid cells and nucleated red blood cells in the peripheral blood
  • This pattern reflects a disruption of the bone marrow architecture, often due to fibrosis or infiltration
  • Primary myelofibrosis (PMF) is classically associated with bone marrow fibrosis, leading to extramedullary hematopoiesis and a leukoerythroblastic blood picture
  • Teardrop-shaped RBCs (dacrocytes) are also commonly seen

Explanation of other options:

Chronic myeloid leukaemia (Option A): Shows a full spectrum of myeloid precursors but lacks erythroid precursors in peripheral blood

Polycythemia vera (Option B): Characterised by erythrocytosis but not typically leukoerythroblastosis

Essential thrombocytosis (Option C): Predominantly increases platelets without immature cells in peripheral blood

Key Takeaways:

  • Leukoerythroblastosis is a hallmark feature of primary myelofibrosis
  • It reflects marrow fibrosis with disrupted hematopoiesis
  • Peripheral smear shows nucleated RBCs, immature myeloid cells, and teardrop RBCs

questions.text: An elderly male presented with a history of intractable diarrhoea. His bone marrow and renal biopsy are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has intractable diarrhoea and renal dysfunction, with biopsy findings indicating systemic involvement
  • Image 1 (Bone marrow): Shows increased plasma cells,a hallmark of multiple myeloma
  • Image 2 (Renal biopsy): Shows eosinophilic, amorphous pink deposits in the glomerulus - classic for amyloid
  • Image 3 (Electron microscopy): Reveals non-branching fibrils, confirming amyloid deposition
  • The diagnosis is multiple myeloma with associated AL amyloidosis affecting the kidneys

Explanation of other options:

Leishmaniasis (Option A): Would show Leishman-Donovan bodies in macrophages; not seen here

Lymphoma (Option C): May cause marrow infiltration but not increased plasma cells or amyloid nephropathy

Urate nephropathy (Option D): Characterised by needle-shaped crystals in tubules, not fibrillar deposits

Key Takeaways:

  • Multiple myeloma may present with plasma cell proliferation and AL amyloidosis
  • Renal amyloidosis presents with proteinuria, glomerular deposits, and fibrils on EM
  • Diagnosis is clinched with plasma cells in the marrow and amyloid features in the kidney

questions.text: A 60-year-old male living in a hilly area has Hb of 16 gm%, TC 21000/mL. DLC showed metamyelocytes and myelocytes 40%, N25% L40%, E5%. Platelet count 3.25 lakh/u. He presented with hypertension, and on examination, the spleen was just palpable below the costal margin. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has polycythemia (Hb = 16 g/dL in a high-altitude setting) with mild splenomegaly and leukocytosis with left shift
  • Since he lives in a hilly area, secondary polycythemia due to hypoxia-induced erythropoiesis is a likely cause
  • Erythropoietin (EPO) levels help distinguish:
    • Primary polycythemia (e.g., Polycythemia vera): Low EPO
    • Secondary polycythemia: High EPO

Explanation of other options:

Bone marrow with reticulin stain (Option A): Evaluates for fibrosis; not the first step here

JAK-STAT mutation assessment (Option B): Useful in polycythemia vera, but done after EPO testing if needed

Philadelphia chromosome (Option C): Suggests CML, but the Hb elevation and geographic clue point to polycythemia, not CML

Key Takeaways:

  • EPO level is the key test to differentiate primary from secondary polycythemia
  • Secondary causes (e.g., high altitude) are associated with elevated EPO
  • Follow-up testing for the JAK2 mutation is appropriate if EPO is low

questions.text: In Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis, the characteristic abnormality seen is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Birbeck granules are rod-shaped cytoplasmic organelles seen in Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH)
  • They appear as "tennis racket-shaped" structures on electron microscopy
  • These granules are unique to Langerhans cells, making them a diagnostic hallmark
  • LCH cells also express CD1a, Langerin (CD207), and S100

Explanation of other options:

Macrophages (Option B): Present in many histiocytic conditions, but not specific to LCH

Plasma cell (Option C): Not involved in LCH; seen in myeloma or chronic inflammation

Giant cell (Option D): Found in granulomatous diseases, not specific for LCH

Key Takeaways:

  • Birbeck granules are pathognomonic for Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis
  • Identified via electron microscopy
  • CD1a and Langerin are key immunohistochemical markers

questions.text: A Male patient attended your OPD with complaints of fever, weight loss and sweats. He complains of easy fatigability and pain in the abdomen. On examination, splenomegaly was present. Investigations, Hb- 7.8 gm% with leukocytosis. Her P/S showed the following picture. What will be the status of BCR-ABL and JAK-2 mutation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with constitutional symptoms (fever, weight loss, sweats), splenomegaly, anaemia, and leukocytosis
  • Peripheral smear shows teardrop-shaped RBCs (dacrocytes) and nucleated red blood cells, which are indicative of leukoerythroblastosis
  • These findings are classic for Primary Myelofibrosis (PMF), a chronic myeloproliferative neoplasm
  • JAK2 V617F mutation is present in ~50-60% of PMF cases (Options A and D ruled out)
  • BCR-ABL translocation is absent in PMF, and its presence would suggest chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML) (Option B ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Leukoerythroblastosis and teardrop RBCs indicate Primary Myelofibrosis
  • BCR-ABL negative, JAK2 mutation positive is the typical molecular profile

Essential to distinguish PMF from CML, which is BCR-ABL positive

questions.text: Russel bodies, Mott bodies and Dutcher bodies seen in?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Russell bodies are eosinophilic immunoglobulin inclusions in the cytoplasm of plasma cells
  • Mott cells are plasma cells packed with Russell bodies
  • Dutcher bodies are intranuclear pseudo-inclusions of immunoglobulin in plasma cells
  • These features are characteristic of plasma cell dyscrasias, including amyloidosis, especially AL amyloidosis, which can involve ocular tissues

Explanation of other options:

Ocular lymphoma (Option B): Typically shows atypical lymphoid cells, not plasma cell inclusions

Ocular sarcoidosis (Option C): Characterised by non-caseating granulomas, not Russell or Dutcher bodies

Ocular tuberculosis (Option D): Shows caseating granulomas; no plasma cell features

Key Takeaways:

  • Russell, Mott, and Dutcher bodies are all derived from abnormal plasma cell activity
  • These are commonly seen in plasma cell dyscrasias, particularly amyloidosis
  • Ocular amyloidosis is associated with plasma cell deposits and immunoglobulin accumulations

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman who presented with aquagenic pruritic had a Hb level of 20g/dL . Her lab investigations are given below,
Hb - 19g/dl
Hematocrit - 52%
S. erythropoietin - decreased
JAK2 mutation - positive
Which of the following is not seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with aquagenic pruritus, elevated haemoglobin, low serum erythropoietin, and positive JAK2 mutation, all of which are diagnostic for Polycythemia Vera (PV)
  • Polycythemia Vera is a chronic myeloproliferative neoplasm characterised by:
    • Clonal proliferation of RBCs, independent of erythropoietin
    • Strong association with JAK2 V617F mutation

Explanation of other options:

Acute Myeloid Leukaemia (Option A): PV can undergo clonal evolution to AML

Budd-Chiari Syndrome (Option B): PV increases the risk of hepatic vein thrombosis

Myelofibrosis (Option C): PV may progress to post-polycythemic myelofibrosis

Key Takeaways:

  • Polycythemia vera presents with elevated Hb, low EPO, aquagenic pruritus, JAK2 mutation
  • Complications include thrombosis, myelofibrosis, and transformation to AML
  • Hepatic failure is not a common or direct feature of PV

questions.text: Match the following Reed-Sternberg (RS) cell variants with their corresponding Hodgkin lymphoma subtype:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Lacunar cells are found in Nodular sclerosis (A-3)
  • Popcorn (L&H) cells are seen in the Nodular lymphocyte predominant subtype (B-4)
  • Mummified RS cells (condensed nuclei) occur in Mixed cellularity (C-2)
  • Pleomorphic RS cells are typical of the Lymphocyte depletion subtype (D-1)

Key Takeaways:

  • Each HL subtype has distinctive RS cell variants
  • Nodular sclerosis → Lacunar
  • NLPHL → L&H (Popcorn)
  • Mixed cellularity → Classic & mummified RS
  • Lymphocyte depletion → Pleomorphic RS
